raw_text:
US duo in first spam conviction
 
 A brother and sister in the US have been convicted of sending hundreds of thousands of unsolicited e-mail messages to AOL subscribers.
 
 It is the first criminal prosecution of internet spam distributors. Jurors in Virginia recommended that the man, Jeremy Jaynes, serve nine years in prison and that his sister, Jessica DeGroot, be fined $7,500. They were convicted under a state law that bars the sending of bulk e-mails using fake addresses.
 
 They will be formally sentenced next year. A third defendant, Richard Rutkowski, was acquitted. Prosecutors said Jaynes was "a snake oil salesman in a new format", using the internet to peddle useless wares, news agency Associated Press reported. A "Fed-Ex refund processor" was supposed to allow people to earn $75 an hour working from home. Another item on sale was an "internet history eraser". His sister helped him process credit card payments. Jaynes amassed a fortune of $24m from his sales, prosecutors said. "He's been successful ripping people off all these years," AP quoted prosecutor Russell McGuire as saying. Jaynes was also found guilty of breaking a state law which prohibits the sending of more than 100,000 e-mails in 30 days, Virginia State Attorney General Jerry Kilgore reportedly said. Prosecutors had asked for 15 years in jail for Jaynes, and a jail term for his sister. But Jaynes' lawyer David Oblon called the nine-year recommended term "outrageous" and said his client believed he was innocent. He pointed out that all three of the accused lived in North Carolina and were unaware of the Virginia state law. Spam messages are estimated to account for at least 60% of all e-mails sent.
llama3.2:1b: A US brother and sister, Jeremy Jaynes and Jessica DeGroot, have been convicted of sending hundreds of thousands of unsolicited e-mail messages to AOL subscribers.
They were found guilty under a Virginia state law that prohibits the sending of bulk e-mails using fake addresses.
The jury recommended that Jaynes serve nine years in prison and his sister be fined $7,500.
llama3.2:3b: A US brother and sister, Jeremy Jaynes and Jessica DeGroot, have been convicted of sending hundreds of thousands of unsolicited emails to AOL subscribers in a criminal prosecution under a state law that bars bulk spam messages using fake addresses.

They were sentenced to nine years in prison and fines of $7,500 respectively.
Prosecutors said they made millions from selling useless products and services via these emails and broke state laws regarding email volume.

They received a nine-year sentence with fines for their criminal prosecution.
Jeremy Jaynes was found guilty of using a state law that bars the sending of more than 100,000 e-mails in 30 days.
His sister Jessica DeGroot was convicted under a different law that forbids spam sending, while Richard Rutkowski was acquitted and his sister helped him process credit card payments.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Two US siblings have been convicted of sending millions of spam emails, becoming the first people prosecuted for distributing unsolicited electronic mail.
Jaynes received a nine-year sentence and his sister $7,500 fine; another defendant was acquitted.
The case highlights the prevalence of email scams and raises concerns about their impact on internet users.
qwen2.5:3b: US duo convicted of spamming AOL subscribers; first such criminal prosecution.
Jeremy Jaynes and Jessica DeGroot received nine years in prison and a $7,500 fine respectively under a state law banning fake addresses.
They used internet to sell fraudulent schemes like an "internet history eraser" and falsely claimed it allowed people to work from home earning up to $75 per hour.
Prosecutors alleged they made over $24 million through fraud.
The trio were acquitted of sending more than 100,000 emails in a month as required by another state law.
Spam messages account for at least 60% of all emails sent.
